## PROJECT OVERVIEW
This project aims to create a simple, yet functional article editor. The editor will allow users to create and edit articles, saving them as JSON and rendering them as HTML.  The project prioritizes a minimal and highly functional design, aiming for maximum efficiency with minimal code. The design emphasizes intuitive user experience and robust error handling. The project is designed for ease of extension with features such as markdown support and real-time collaboration planned for future development.  The project utilizes a modular design, separating concerns into distinct modules for easier maintenance and extension. Robust error handling and input sanitization are implemented throughout the application to prevent vulnerabilities and ensure a smooth user experience. A debounce function is used to optimize auto-save functionality, preventing excessive storage writes. The project implements a clear and well-defined release process, including versioning and deployment steps. The project is designed to be used offline. Article data is stored in the browser's localStorage and IndexDB, and can be exported and imported as JSON files. Analysis of the `archive` folder revealed previous iterations of the project, including various configuration files, documentation, and code examples. This information provides valuable context for understanding the project's evolution and current state. The project now includes a real-time search functionality. A new `knowledge-base` directory has been created to house the core application code. The project will utilize a two-hour sprint development workflow. The project will utilize a real-time search system that displays results as the user types, applying a debounce function to prevent unnecessary searches and utilizing the IndexDB for speed. The search will support both title and full-text search, displaying results in order of relevance. The project now includes a speech synthesis feature (added 2025-04-05). The project now supports full-text search of article titles, categories, tags, and component content (added 2025-04-05). The project will implement a minimal locking mechanism to prevent concurrent edits of the same article. Articles will be exported as JSON files upon creation and updated automatically. The project will utilize a minimal UI/UX design, focusing on core functionality and ease of use. The project data structure will be minimal and efficient, focusing on core content elements. (2025-04-05) The project is designed for offline use, utilizing IndexDB for persistent storage and localStorage for temporary data. A simple locking mechanism prevents concurrent edits of the same article. Articles are exported as JSON upon creation and updated automatically. The UI/UX emphasizes simplicity and ease of use. ## CODE STYLE
- Follow standard JavaScript coding conventions (e.g., consistent indentation, meaningful variable names).
- Keep functions small and focused (ideally under 15 lines).
- Minimize nesting levels (aim for 3 levels or less).
- Prioritize self-documenting code over extensive comments.
- Use template literals for efficient HTML generation.
- Implement robust error handling using try/catch blocks and user-friendly error messages.
- Implement input sanitization to prevent XSS vulnerabilities.
- Implement debounce function for auto-save and search functionality.
- Use modular design to encapsulate related functionality.
- Utilize event-driven architecture to separate UI events from state changes.
- Implement consistent and clear naming conventions for variables and functions.
- Limit file size to under 500 lines of code.  This has been relaxed to accommodate the single-file application and multiple file approaches (2025-04-05).  The target size range is 700-2000 lines. (2025-04-05)  The target code size is estimated at 200-350 lines of code for a minimal implementation, potentially reducible to 200-250 lines by further simplification. (2025-04-05)
- Maintain a consistent and readable code style throughout the project.  (2025-04-05)
- Use clear and concise variable and function names.  (2025-04-05)
- Minimize the use of nested conditional statements and loops. (2025-04-05)
- Inline CSS will be used for HTML styling. (2025-04-05)


## FOLDER ORGANIZATION
- `/knowledge-base`: Contains the core article editor code. The project structure has been reorganized (2025-04-05) to reflect the new design.  The organization may be further refined to support either a single-file or multi-file approach. (2025-04-05) The folder structure should be kept simple and intuitive. (2025-04-05) The project follows a modular structure, separating concerns into distinct modules for easier maintenance and scalability. (2025-04-05)  The primary functionality will be contained within a single HTML file (`editor.html`), including all JavaScript and HTML. (2025-04-05).  The `Main` directory contains the `js/editor.js` file (2025-04-05).  The `Main` directory also contains `json-to-html-conversion-rules.md` (2025-04-05).  The `Main` directory now contains `json-to-html-conversion-rules.md`, a markdown file detailing the JSON to HTML conversion rules. (2025-04-05)
- `/article-editor`: Contains the core article editor code (index.html, js/, css/, data/). This directory is now largely superseded by `/knowledge-base` and may be removed in future versions. (2025-04-05)
- `/archive`: Contains previous project files, organized into subfolders:
    - `/archive/git_and_configs`: Contains .git, .cursor, and .specstory folders.
    - `/archive/old_config`: Contains old configuration files.
    - `/archive/old_config_files`: Contains old configuration files (e.g., ESLint, Stylelint).
    - `/archive/old_docs`: Contains old documentation files and HTML files.
    - `/archive/old_files`: Contains old project files, including `backup`, `css`, `js`, `lib`, `node_modules`, `rebuild`, `samples`, `src`, and `styles` subfolders.
    - `/archive/reference_files`: Contains HTML, CSS, JS, and MD files for reference.


## TECH STACK
- Vanilla JavaScript (ES6+)
- HTML5
- CSS3 (Inline CSS will be used. 2025-04-05)
- IndexDB (Added 2025-04-05)


## PROJECT-SPECIFIC STANDARDS
- Article data will be stored in JSON format and IndexDB.  The JSON structure will be minimal and efficient, focusing on core content elements.  See the example below.  The schema will include `id`, `title`, `category`, `author`, `createdAt`, `updatedAt`, `tags`, and `content` fields. The `content` field will be an array of content blocks, each with a `type` property and data specific to the block type (e.g., heading, paragraph, image, list). (2025-04-05)
- HTML will be generated dynamically from JSON data.  A dedicated function for JSON to HTML conversion is implemented in `article-editor/js/converter.js` and utilized in `Main/js/editor.js` (2025-04-05).  The conversion process uses only HTML tags and inline CSS for styling. (2025-04-05)
- LocalStorage will be used for temporary storage of drafts and article lists.
- The UI will be kept simple and intuitive.  The design will prioritize clarity and ease of use.
- The project utilizes a modular design, separating concerns into distinct modules for easier maintenance and extension. This design is maintained through functional organization, regardless of whether a single-file or multi-file approach is used. (2025-04-05)
- Robust error handling and input sanitization are implemented throughout the application to prevent vulnerabilities and ensure a smooth user experience.
- A debounce function is used to optimize auto-save and search functionality, preventing excessive storage writes.
- Real-time search functionality will be implemented using IndexDB for fast response times. Debounce will be used to optimize search queries. Title and full-text search will be supported. Results will be displayed in order of relevance. Search results will be displayed as the user types, with a debounce function to prevent unnecessary searches. The search will utilize IndexDB for speed and will support both title and full-text search, displaying results in order of relevance. Search results will be displayed immediately as the user types, with a debounce function to prevent unnecessary searches. The search will now support full-text search of article titles, categories, tags, and component content (added 2025-04-05). A minimal locking mechanism will be implemented to prevent concurrent edits. Articles will be exported as JSON files upon creation and updated automatically. The UI should be minimal and intuitive, prioritizing core functionality and ease of use. (2025-04-05) All articles will be exportable as JSON files. (2025-04-05) A simple locking mechanism will be implemented to prevent concurrent edits. (2025-04-05) The project will use a simple locking mechanism to prevent concurrent edits of the same article. Articles will be exported as JSON files upon creation and updated automatically. The project will support the creation and editing of articles with basic components such as headings, paragraphs, and images. (2025-04-05) The application will be a single HTML file (`editor.html`) containing all JavaScript and HTML. (2025-04-05)  The application is designed to be under 1500 lines of code, but this may vary based on the chosen design (700-2000 lines). (2025-04-05).  The target code size is estimated to be between 700 and 2000 lines, depending on features and whether a single-file or multi-file approach is used. (2025-04-05)  A minimal feature set, including full-text search, is estimated at 800-1000 lines of code. (2025-04-05) A discussion on 2025-04-05 suggested a simpler editor design using a horizontal list of content blocks for editing, aiming for a single-page layout without scrolling. (2025-04-05) A simpler design using a horizontal list of content blocks for editing on a single page without scrolling was discussed on 2025-04-05. (2025-04-05) The target code size is estimated at 200-350 lines of code for a minimal implementation, potentially reducible to 200-250 lines by further simplification. (2025-04-05)  The project will utilize a horizontal list for editing content blocks, aiming for a single-page layout without scrolling.  The target code size for a minimal implementation is 200-350 lines, potentially reducible to 200-250 lines.  The final design will utilize a horizontal list for content block editing on a single page without scrolling. Example JSON Structure:
```json
{
  "id": "article-123",
  "title": "è¨˜äº‹ã‚¿ã‚¤ãƒˆãƒ«",
  "summary": "æ¦‚è¦æ–‡",
  "tags": ["ã‚¿ã‚°1", "ã‚¿ã‚°2"],
  "category": "ã‚«ãƒ†ã‚´ãƒª",
  "date": "2024-04-03T10:00:00Z",
  "content": [
    {
      "type": "heading",
      "level": 2,
      "text": "è¦‹å‡ºã—"
    },
    {
      "type": "paragraph",
      "text": "æ®µè½ãƒ†ã‚­ã‚¹ãƒˆ"
    },
    {
      "type": "list",
      "style": "bullet",
      "items": ["é …ç›®1", "é …ç›®2"]
    },
    {
      "type": "image",
      "src": "image.jpg",
      "alt": "ç”»åƒã®èª¬æ˜",
      "caption": "ç”»åƒã®èª¬æ˜æ–‡",
      "width": "50%",
      "align": "center",
      "height": "auto"
    }
  ]
}
```

```javascript
/**
  * è¨˜äº‹ã®JSONã‚¹ã‚­ãƒ¼ãƒå®šç¾©
  * ã“ã®ã‚¹ã‚­ãƒ¼ãƒã¯è¨˜äº‹ãƒ‡ãƒ¼ã‚¿ã®æ§‹é€ ã‚’å®šç¾©ã—ã¾ã™
  */

// è¨˜äº‹ã‚¹ã‚­ãƒ¼ãƒã®åŸºæœ¬æ§‹é€ 
const articleSchema = {
  // è¨˜äº‹ã®åŸºæœ¬æƒ…å ±
  id: "", // è¨˜äº‹ã®ä¸€æ„è­˜åˆ¥å­ï¼ˆè‡ªå‹•ç”Ÿæˆï¼‰
  title: "", // è¨˜äº‹ã®ã‚¿ã‚¤ãƒˆãƒ«
  category: "", // ã‚«ãƒ†ã‚´ãƒª
  author: "", // ä½œæˆè€…
  createdAt: "", // ä½œæˆæ—¥æ™‚ï¼ˆISOå½¢å¼ï¼šYYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZï¼‰
  updatedAt: "", // æ›´æ–°æ—¥æ™‚ï¼ˆISOå½¢å¼ï¼šYYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZï¼‰
  tags: [], // ã‚¿ã‚°ã®é…åˆ—

  // è¨˜äº‹ã®å†…å®¹ï¼ˆè¤‡æ•°ã®ãƒ–ãƒ­ãƒƒã‚¯ã§æ§‹æˆï¼‰
  content: [
    // å„ãƒ–ãƒ­ãƒƒã‚¯ã¯typeãƒ—ãƒ­ãƒ‘ãƒ†ã‚£ã‚’æŒã¡ã€ã‚¿ã‚¤ãƒ—ã«ã‚ˆã£ã¦è¿½åŠ ã®ãƒ—ãƒ­ãƒ‘ãƒ†ã‚£ã‚’æŒã¤
    // ä¾‹ï¼š
    // { 
    //   type: "heading", 
    //   level: 1, 
    //   text: "è¦‹å‡ºã—ãƒ†ã‚­ã‚¹ãƒˆ" 
    // }
  ]
};

/**
  * ã‚³ãƒ³ãƒ†ãƒ³ãƒ„ãƒ–ãƒ­ãƒƒã‚¯ã®ãƒ†ãƒ³ãƒ—ãƒ¬ãƒ¼ãƒˆå®šç¾©
  * å„ã‚³ãƒ³ãƒ†ãƒ³ãƒ„ã‚¿ã‚¤ãƒ—ã®æ§‹é€ ã‚’å®šç¾©ã—ã¾ã™
  */

// è¦‹å‡ºã—ãƒ–ãƒ­ãƒƒã‚¯ã®ãƒ†ãƒ³ãƒ—ãƒ¬ãƒ¼ãƒˆ
const headingBlock = {
  type: "heading", // ãƒ–ãƒ­ãƒƒã‚¯ã‚¿ã‚¤ãƒ—ï¼šè¦‹å‡ºã—
  level: 2,        // è¦‹å‡ºã—ãƒ¬ãƒ™ãƒ«ï¼ˆ1ã€œ6ï¼‰ã€ãƒ‡ãƒ•ã‚©ãƒ«ãƒˆã¯2
  text: ""         // è¦‹å‡ºã—ã®ãƒ†ã‚­ã‚¹ãƒˆå†…å®¹
};
```

## WORKFLOW & RELEASE RULES
- Use Git for version control.
- Commit frequently with clear and concise commit messages.
- Follow a consistent branching strategy (e.g., feature branches).
- Implement thorough testing before release. Prioritize unit and integration testing.
- Implement a clear and well-defined release process, including versioning and deployment steps.
- Two-hour development sprints are now standard.  (2025-04-05)  Focus on iterative development and frequent releases. (2025-04-05)  The project uses a two-hour sprint development workflow to ensure rapid iteration and quick releases. (2025-04-05)

Additionally, the `archive` directory contains previous project iterations for context and learning.  Analysis of these archived files will help in understanding the project's development history and design decisions.
